bibl.title: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, May 25, 1923

div1.p: Barber writes that he is monitoring mosquitoes and putting together statistics about types of malaria.

div1.head: Letter from M.A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, May 25, 1923
div1.opener:
N. M. C
Barber
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Crowley, La. May 25, 1923.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have received your very kind letter of May 17
with the information regarding Chara and the van Ezdorf records. I have
been on the lookout for Chara here, but have found none thus far. Will
keep watch for it

I am getting together some statistics as regards malaria types.
By months over several years are about 1860 positives from Dr. Thibault
of Ark. and some 1300 from Memphis. Besides I have shorter periods
of ones I obtained in Ga. and Ala. and some from Ark. Charity hospital
New Orleans turned over their records to me and I worked out 5 years there.
Only a relatively small number of cases Charity Hosp have the pathologist's report of blood
findings by types, so the total was only about 225. Dr. Bass gave me
his delta records, but these were done for another purpose and the type
of malaria not specially sought--mostly thick films and by technicians.
Just got a fine short series from Miss Moss at Ark. Also have the
amount absolute malaria cases and rates per 1000 of all the army camps by months
1917 and 1918, but not by types. I shall see what I can get of the types--
we typed our cases in Camp Jackson, S.C. but cases by types may not be on
record.

Salt marsh crucians now very plenty here, biting fiercely in broad
daylight, that is near the marshes. We have found only one walkeri, but have
hopes of finding more later in the season, or earlier next year.
